October 26, 2014: Fiction
DEADLINE, by John Sandford. (Putnam.) Dognappers and a murdered reporter
draw the attention of the Minnesota investigator Virgil Flowers.
BURN, by James Patterson and Michael Ledwidge. (Little, Brown.) Detective
Michael Bennett, back in New York City, investigates a peculiar crime in Harlem.
EDGE OF ETERNITY, by Ken Follett. (Dutton.) Five interrelated families from five
countries grapple with the events of the 1960s through the 1980s; Book 3 of the
Century Trilogy.
LILA, by Marilynne Robinson. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux.) The difficult early life of
the woman who becomes the wife of the widower and minister John Ames; a back
story to "Gilead."
SOMEWHERE SAFE WITH SOMEBODY GOOD, by Jan Karon. (Putnam.) The
Mitford character Father Tim finds friends and family wrestling with difficulties.
PERSONAL, by Lee Child. (Delacorte.) Jack Reacher, a former military cop, helps
the State Department and the C.I.A. stop a sniper who has targeted a G8 summit.
ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE, by Anthony Doerr. (Scribner.) The lives of a
blind French girl and a gadget-obsessed German boy before and during World
War II.
SOME LUCK, by Jane Smiley. (Knopf.) The lives of an Iowa farm family between
1920 and 1953; the first volume of a trilogy.
PARIS MATCH, by Stuart Woods. (Putnam.) In the 31st Stone Barrington novel,
the New York lawyer encounters an old enemy in Paris.
THE CHILDREN ACT, by Ian McEwan. (Nan A. Talese/ Doubleday.) A judge
wrestles with a challenging case and a crisis in her marriage.
BIG LITTLE LIES, by Liane Moriarty. (Amy Einhorn/Putnam.) Who will end up
dead, and how, when three mothers with children in the same school become
friends?
THE GOLDFINCH, by Donna Tartt. (Little, Brown.)  A painting becomes a boy’s
prize, guilt and burden.
THE PAYING GUESTS, by Sarah Waters. (Riverhead.) In London in 1922, a
widow and her daughter take in tenants who upend their lives.
NORA WEBSTER, by Colm Toibin. (Scribner.) In the 1970s, an Irish widow
struggles to find her identity.
THE ASSASSINATION OF MARGARET THATCHER, by Hilary Mantel.
October 26, 2014
Non-Fiction
KILLING PATTON, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt.) The host of “The
O’Reilly Factor” recounts the death of Gen. George S. Patton in December 1945.
NOT THAT KIND OF GIRL, by Lena Dunham. (Random House.) A collection of
revealing and often humorous personal essays from the creator and star of “Girls.”
BEING MORTAL, by Atul Gawande. (Metropolitan/ Holt.) The surgeon and New
Yorker writer considers how doctors fail patients at the end of life, and how they
can do better.
THE INNOVATORS, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster.) Studies of the
people who created computers and the Internet, beginning in the 1840s.
STOP THE COMING CIVIL WAR, by Michael Savage. (Center Street.) The radio
host urges true patriots to save the country from the machinations of the left.
WORTHY FIGHTS, by Leon Panetta with Jim Newton. (Penguin Press.) The
writer's experience in the Obama administration as director of the C.I.A. and
secretary of defense.
WHAT IF?, by Randall Munroe. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.) Scientific (but often
humorous) answers to hypothetical questions, based in part on the author’s
website, xkcd.com.
ROCKS, by Joe Perry with David Ritz. (Simon & Schuster.) A memoir by the
Aerosmith guitarist and songwriter.
JESUS ON TRIAL, by David Limbaugh. (Regnery.) The lawyer and political
commentator uses his legal training to evaluate, and affirm, the truthfulness of the
Bible.
13 HOURS, by Mitchell Zuckoff with members of the Annex Security Team.
(Twelve.) Six C.I.A. contract employees discuss their experience during the attack
on the State Department compound in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012.
WAKING UP, by Sam Harris. (Simon & Schuster.) The author of “The End of
Faith” proposes that spirituality can and should be divorced from religion.
REBEL YELL, by S. C. Gwynne. (Scribner.) The life and career of the Confederate
general Stonewall Jackson.
DANCING WITH MYSELF, by Billy Idol. (Touchstone.) The punk pioneer's
autobiography.
HOW WE GOT TO NOW, by Steven Johnson. (Riverhead.) A history of innovation
focused on the development of six key technologies of modern life; the companion
volume to a PBS series.
